ART & WINE

At Chateau Lascombes

Great wines in Magnums! Will add lustre to any cellar, particu ‘ pa, larly at these very low prices. Some of you may recall our catalog of last winter with its y y E colorful Van Gogh cover, an introduction by Clifton Fadiman, and an article by Dr. Alfred Frankfurter. These two eminent critics developed the thesis that there is a link between art and wine. And now another event that symbolizes this relationship, RED WINES takes place in the little wine town of Margaux, in the Bordeaux district, right in the midst of the vineyards. For, at Chateau Lascombes, whose wines are appreciated throughout the world, there is an important art exhibit on the subject of “Wine and the CHATEAU LA TOUR CARNET 1959 4.18 Vine”. This intriguing concept was developed by Alexis Lichine me es ZF and has won the plaudits of the art critics of France. Not only is CHATEAU HAUT BRION 1958 7.9 Alexis Lichine the Managing Director of Chateau Lascombes, CHATEAU HAUT BRION 1953 14.98

and an internationally famous wine authority, but evidently is a CHATEAU DE MONTHELIE 1959 5.20

most persuasive individual. It was not an easy task to be able to gather, all under one roof at the Chateau, the excellent works of sixty recognized French, and thirty outstanding Italian artists. All of the 250 paintings on exhibit are related to the theme of wine.

Some of you may be in France this summer and would gladly detour off the main road to experience a restaurant that has earned three stars in the Guide Michelin. And we genuinely be- lieve that visiting Chateau Lascombes and its gallery is equally worth a major detour.

You will be greeted warmly and made welcome by Alexis Lichine and his staff. They will proudly tell you all about the vineyards of the Medoc, the process of wine-making there, and enthusiastically join you. while you taste and appraise the more recent vintages. The exhibit will be on continuous display, until the last grapes of the autumn vintage are gathered—-and you will be made welcome .every day, including Sundays, ‘until the hour of 7 P.M.
